presentation.title: Coastal Protection in MG
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from natural protecting of coasts in Madagascar (no flows)
presentation.description: Assessment of potential source, use and sinks related to ecosystems protecting coastal environments in Madagascar. This fast-running model does not include ecosystem service flow analysis.

page.name: Coastal Protection assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline, developed with financial support from the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre, describes aspects of coastal flood regulation in Madagascar. This island's coastal ecosystems include dunes, coral reefs, seagrass, and mangroves, all of which play a role in dissipating wind and wave energy generated by coastal storms. Unlike more northerly nations bordering the Indian Ocean, Madagascar is rarely subject to earthquake-generated tsunami waves. However, eastern Madagascar is highly susceptible to tropical storms coming off the southwestern Indian Ocean. Its storms are relatively poorly studied, with limited infrastructure for measuring and modeling storm magnitude and impact versus other tropical storm prone regions in more developed parts of the world (Naeraa and Jury 1998).

The coastal storm protection models used here are intended as a proof-of-concept framework to spatially link: 1) storm wave sources; 2) ecosystem “sinks” that mitigate wave damage; and 3) social groups or assets that are susceptible to harm by coastal flooding. These models use historic storm track, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure data from tropical storms that occurred in a specified region of time. Tropical Storms Daisy, Geralda, and Litanne, three severe storms that made landfall near the port of Toamasina in 1994, are used in the first version of this model, based on availability of information from Naeraa and Jury (1998). The Authors modeled aspects of these storms and their attendant storm surges, providing data for calibration of model results. Our model can easily be applied to other historical storm tracks in Madagascar and to simulated future storm tracks, or to other simulated large wave events, such as tsunamis. These models can also be relatively easily generalized to other parts of the world, as they rely on global datasets for historical storms, coastal ecosystems capable of mitigating storm surges, and lives and property at risk of flood damage.
page.see-also:
Naeraa, M. and M.R. Jury. 1998. Tropical cyclone composite structure and impacts over Eastern Madagascar during January-March 1994. Meteorology and Atmospheric Physics 65: 43-53.
The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Model development: Ken Bagstad, Gary Johnson, Brian Voigt, Ferdinando Villa.
Funding and data support: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Lives At Risk Storm
page.title: Lives At Risk Storm
page.description: This model considers the populations that live directly on the coasts as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. As such, the population density in coastal areas is identified as the use model and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: CIESIN Columbia University
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Storm-sensitive assets
page.title: Storm-sensitive assets
page.description:
This model considers economically valuable assets as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Such data are available directly and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
Data about economic value put directly at risk by coastal storms is published by CIESIN and is used directly.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: CIESIN Columbia University
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Sensitive value
page.title: Storm-sensitive economic value
page.description:
This model considers economically valuable assets as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Such data are available directly and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
Data about economic value put directly at risk by coastal storms is published by CIESIN and is used directly.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: CIESIN Columbia University
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.
page.runninghead: Assets at risk for tropical storms

page.name: Lives at risk
page.title: Lives at risk for tropical storms
page.description:
This model considers the populations that live directly on the coasts as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. As such, the population density in coastal areas is identified as the use model and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
Data about the number of lives put directly at risk by coastal storms is published by CIESIN and is used directly.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wind Speed
page.title: Wind Speed
page.description: Wind speed, obtained here from historical storm records, is proportional to the total potential damage inflicted by wind and waves and is used in the flow model to quantify the amount of damaging energy reaching coastal population or prevented from doing so by natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Seagrass
page.title: Seagrass Presence
page.description: Seagrass beds, along with other vegetational and geomorphological features, are valuable in intercepting the wave front and capturing energy that would otherwise inflict damage to the coast. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms and tsunamis.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mangroves Presence
page.title: Mangroves Presence
page.description: Mangroves, along with other vegetational and geomorphological features, are extremely valuable in capturing wave and wind energy and therefore reducing the damage from coastal storms. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms and tsunamis.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Bathymetric Slope
page.title: Bathymetric Slope
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Storm Surge
page.title: Storm Surge
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Artificial Coastal Protection
page.title: Artificial Coastal Protection
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coral Quality
page.title: Coral Quality
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Geomorphic Protection
page.title: Geomorphic Flood Protection
page.description:
The amount of the total wind and wave energy that is generate by storms and reaches the coast depends on many factors, including the geomorphology of the area. This map is a probabilistic assessment of the total protection provided by geomorphic features such as sea floor depth, slope, or terrestrial elevation.
These data are used as input to the sink model, which establishes the total protection potential determined by natural features. The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and intercepted by natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Vegetation
page.title: Terrestrial Vegetation
page.description:
The type of terrestrial vegetation encountered on the coast is an important determinant of how much wave and wind energy can be absorbed by the ecosystem before it reaches humans assets and settlements.
These data are used as input to the sink model, which establishes the total protection potential determined by natural features. The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and intercepted by natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Dunes
page.title: Dune Presence
page.description: Dunes and bathymetric configuration account for the bulk of natural coastal protection in areas where mangroves and seagrass are scarce. These data are used as input to the sink model, which establishes the total protection potential determined by natural features. The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and intercepted by natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Flood Protection
page.title: Total Storm Protection
page.description:
This map is the probabilistic assessment of the *sink* model, which puts together all the potentially preventative features of the landscape into a single map. Each point of the map details the likely amount of damaging energy that can be intercepted by such features.
The flow model uses this map to determine whether each point can deplete the energy coming from the storm front, thereby reducing the total amount of damage that reaches the users.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wave source
page.title: Coastal wave source
page.description:
The quantity of coastal waves generated at a certain part of the land or seascape. This is the main source of the wave threat created by storms and tsunamis and intercepted by natural features along the coasts. It is computed by processing historical storm records along recorded storm tracks.
The source data are used as input to the flow model that computes how much wave energy is dissipated by ecosystems and green infrastructure, and how much protection benefit is accrued by humans in the process. Therefore, these source data do not account for flows.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wave mitigation
page.title: Potential wave mitigation
page.description:
The *sink* model computes the amount of service carrier intercepted along the flow paths. In all preventative services like coastal flood protection, the sink model represents the source of actual benefit to humans, as it reduces the amount of damaging carrier (in this case, wave energy) capable of inflicting damage to the users.
This map of potential wave mitigation is a probabilistic compendium of all ecosystem-related factors likely to intercept wave energy alogn their damaging path towards the coast. As all maps of "potential", it is used as an input to the flow model and therefore does not account for flows.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Vulnerable groups
page.title: Potentially wave-vulnerable populations
page.description:
The use model, in preventative services like coastal flood protection, is used as an input to the flow models to identify the areas of need for the service and quantify the need and its probability. This map identifies all the potential users of coastal flood protection, and is computed by determining the probability that people or economically valuable assets are located in flood zones.
This map, like all "potential" maps, is used as input and does not account for flows.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging wave flow
page.description:
Potential flow maps represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. In provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; in preventative services, the maximum potential damage.
This specific map shows the flow route of wave energy across the land and seascape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows computing the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential waves
page.title: Source of potentially damaging waves
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all the source component actually has the ability of flowing to the users, because of the details of how the carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows to identify which particular portion of the total source field is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use analysis, the structure of the landscape and the modalities of transmission of the carrier. In provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. In preventative services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that needs to be worried about. The configuration of sinks will decide how much of this source actually reaches the users.
This specific map represents what specific sources of waves are capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential wave damage
page.description: People and property receiving damage when accounting for sources of wind or waves and their flow paths but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from wind or waves.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual waves
page.title: Actual wave flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map depicts the trajectories that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected among the total flow density to only show these trajectories that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
In provisioning services, these trajectories deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. In preventative services, the trajectories show how much of the carrier gets to users, delivering actual damage.
In this specific case, the density of actual flows represent the wave energy that hits users and assets, after accounting for their routing due to winds, geophysics, and natural features that deplete their magnitude.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging wave source
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is actually relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. In provisioning services, this is the part of the benefitshed that is actually providing benefits to the users. In preventative services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Those parts of the provisionshed that could be damaging but have been neutralized by sinks are not shown.
In this case, the map shows the source of those waves that actually harm people or damage property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized wave mitigation
page.description: Utilized wind mitigation: Sinks that actively reduce wind or waves, providing the benefit of reduced flood or wind damage for people.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Wave damage received
page.description: Actual damage received by people and property when accounting for sources of wind or waves and their sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Benign waves
page.title: Benign wave source
page.description:
The *unused source map" reveals those areas of the source map whose values do not influence the delivery of the service, because of the impossibility of reaching users given the dynamics of ecosystem services flow. In provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. In preventative services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because of the flow dynamics prevents the carrier from reaching any significant user.
In this specific case, the map shows wind or waves that do not have people or economically valuable assets lying in their path.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Unused protection
page.title: Unutilized wave mitigation
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sink map that actually contributes to depleting the carrier of the service given its patterns of flow. In provisioning services, such sinks are responsible of reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. In preventative services, such sinks are responsible for the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching the users.
In this case, the image shows those sinks that actively reduce wind or waves, providing the benefit of reduced flood or wind damage for people.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Absorbed waves
page.title: Absorbed wave flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* depicts the trajectories that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow dynamics and the source and user configuration, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected among the total flow density.
In provisioning services, these trajectories show the loss in possible flow of services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. In preventative services, the trajectories show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features to produce damage.
In this specific case, the map shows flood or wind flows that are absorbed by natural features prior to reaching human beneficiaries of wind or wave regulation.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mitigated waves
page.title: Mitigated wave source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the dynamic of flow, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. In provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. In preventative services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted to users but was blocked by natural features.
In this specific case, the map shows the portion of coastal wind and wave front whose damage is reduced or nullified by the action of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Wave mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the carrier of the services based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. In provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued by users because of sinks; in preventative services, it shows actual value being accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
In preventative services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the configuration of users and natural features.
In this case, the map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from coastal flood or wind damage due to the flood or wind regulation activity of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.
